Title: Meet Joe Black
Author: Bo Goldman  Ron Osborn  Jeff Reno  Kevin Wade

Replies.Reply: 'Yes' is the answer to your question.
Try.  Because 'if you haven't tried, you haven't lived'.
No, you're not.  You're trying to 'handle' the situation but this is the one situation you knew you never could handle.
There's going to be plenty of time for that.
What are you looking so provoked about?  'Did you miss me?'  It's a normal question.  I missed you.
I'm waiting outside.  Won't someone come to the door?
The great Bill Parrish at a loss for words?  The man from whose lips fall 'rapture' and 'passion' and 'obses-

Just think of millenniums multiplied by aeons compounded by infinity, I've been around that long, but it's only recently that your affairs here have piqued my interest.  Call it boredom, the natural curiosity of me, the most lasting and significant element in existence has come to see you.
I want to have a look around before I take you.
It requires competence, wisdom, experience -- all those things they say about you in testimonials --
Show me around.  Be my guide.  And in return, you get...
In return you'll receive minuets, days, weeks, I'm not going to go into details ... what matters is that I stay interested.
'Yes' is the answer to your ques-

Bill.  Come on.  The question.  The question you've been asking yourself with increased regularity, at odd moments, panting through the extra game of handball, when you ran for the plane in Delhi, when you sat up in bed last night and hit the floor in the office this morning.  The question that is in the back of your throat, choking the blood to your brain, ringing in the ears over and over as you put it to yourself --
Paint is rust and moss green.
Freesia, freesia, everywhere.  Daddy loves freesia -- and you, over there, lights.  Not too bright.  I'm looking for a saffron glow -- sort of tea-
You've got patients waiting, I've got three hysterical chefs, one loves truffles, the other hates truffles, the third one doesn't know what truffles are.  I'd better drive down.
Calm down, Daddy, you'll see, you're going to love it.
Remember everybody, tonight, dinner in the city at Daddy's.  You too, Drew.  We've still got some loose ends --

...Music, I know how you love music, Daddy, and I want to have music that pleases you -- and of course doesn't put a thousand other people to sleep -- I've agonized over this and finally settled on Sidney Brown, twenty-four men, very eclectic, plus I'm feathering in a Latin sextet on their breaks - Tito Puente, Trini Lopez-zy, I forget their names --
You haven't heard a word, have you?
I lay awake nights in a cold sweat, I want this party to be like some-
Good.  Songs.  What songs should Sidney -- Pancho and his six men we can forget about -- what songs do you think he should play?
Never mind.  Leave it to me.
Did you speak to the Governor?

Please don't be negative, Drew, we have an acceptance list that would do The White House proud -- The Secretary-General of the UN, the Chairman of the FCC, nine Senators, I don't know how many Congressmen, and at least twelve of the Fortune '500'.
I've arranged for favors -- silver charm bracelets for the women, platinum keychains for the men --
Are they ordinary?  Do they seem that way to you, Daddy?
Hello, how nice to meet you.  And wouldn't it be nicer if my father would introduce you?
Daddy.  Does your friend have a name?
Whew, at last.  Nice to meet you, Mr. Black.
And isn't it a lovely one?  So sturdy, so straight --
Now, I'm getting interested.  I want to know more ---
...We're never all together two nights in a row.  Maybe Christmas, Thanksgiving, that's it.  What's going on?
...I don't know, Daddy seems funny to me.  Ever since Joe showed.  It's like he dropped from the clouds...
...When Daddy walked in with him, he couldn't even remember his name.  Now he's his house guest.  And you know how he hates house guests.  What is going on?
-- But he does seem very nice.
Did you know twenty-six members of your rifle company are coming?
Whatever it was, they'll be here.
You know, we're going to give this party for you whether you like it or not.
Daddy, you could sit down if you wanted to.
Did he?  That's more than we get to do.
From La Rosette, only the greatest pastry chef in America.
This is orange, from real Seville oranges.  Lemon, on a mille-feuille crust, a little on the fanciful.
I knew you were going to say that.
Hi, Daddy, what do you think?
The fountain is the Caspian Sea and the Sea is serving up caviar.  The 'B's for Beluga, the 'P' for Petrossian.  Of course, they also stand for 'Bill' and for 'Parrish'.
-- Plus we've got a baritone with a balalaika coming from The Russian Tea Room.  I've dressed him in a Cossack shirt and he'll sing Nelson Eddy songs.
I do it because I love you.  Because everybody I loved you.  Mommy -- wher-
They respect you.  Isn't that a kind of love?
Above all, you've been a wonderful father.
But that's what you were thinking.
I already feel I've had everything I could have wanted for my birthday --
What's going on here?  Tete-a-tetes on my big night?
Daddy!  We've been looking all over for you - this is your party - what are you doing in here?  Never mind.
What do you think of all this, May?
Oh, the President's got better things to do than come to my birthday party.
Not much more.  Big day in the big city.  What's on your mind?
Allison, I trust you.  This is your thing.
Isn't it enough to be on this earth sixty-five years without having to be reminded of it.
Good morning, Drew.  Thanks for coming out.
'Thoughts'?  Not a one -- but I did hear a voice last night.
Maybe, who knows?  You know how voices are.  Let's go.
Thank God.  Now could we go?  Let's get this day started.
I know it's none of my business --
Forget about me and Mom -- are you going to marry him?
Susan, you're a hell of a woman.
Well, I wasn't going to say that --
Listen, I'm crazy about the guy --
That's for me.  I'm talking about you.  It's not so much what you say about Drew, it's what you don't say.
Oh yes, I am.  Not an ounce of excitement, not a whisper of a thrill, this relationship has all the passion of a pair of titmice.
Well, it worries me.  I want you to get swept away.  I want you to levitate.  I want you to sing with rapture and dance like a dervish.
Be deliriously happy.  Or at least leave yourself open to be.

I know it's a cornball thing but love is passion, obsession, someone you can't live without.  If you don't start with that, what are you going to end up with?  I say fall head over heels.  Find someone you can love like crazy and who'll love you the same way back.  And how do you find him?  Forget your head and listen to your heart.  I'm not hearing any heart.

Run the risk, if you get hurt, you'll come back.  Because, the truth is there is no sense living your life without this.  To make the journey and not fall deeply in love -- well, you haven't lived a life at all.
Stay open.  Who knows?  Lightning could strike.
You won't tell him, and even if you did, he'd clock it and punch it into his laptop in order to pull out some key phrases when he gives the Commencement Speech at Wharton.
I know.  But I'm the only father you've got.
He doesn't care.  But thanks anyway.
Just talking to myself again.  You know me --
A-Okay.  Got my gloves on, my ears pricked.  I'm ready for action.
Do you think I need a haircut?
Our first annual report, must be thirty-five years ago now, I owned two stations, I wrote down a state-
Good, good.  Glad to hear it.
I thought you were buying my company.
Well, that's very nice to hear.
Like a marriage made in heaven?
As close as a deal could be.
What is this?  Who is this fucking guy?
Where are you?  Are you there?
Oh, you couldn't be more wrong, sweetheart.  I can' tell you how much I appreciate it and how I'm looking forward to it.
Show him into the library, tell him I'll be right there.
Uh -- I don't know.  No - uh - I don't...
What is this, a joke, right?  Some kind of elaborate practical joke?
What the hell is this?  Who are you?
What the hell are you talking about?
You're coming to 'take me'.  What is that?  Who the hell are you?
You're not Death.  You're just a kid in a jacket and a pair of pants.
You want me to be your guide --?
How long will you be staying?
This is crazy -- you're not going to eat dinner with us.
Excuse me?  Could I say something?
When I introduce you, if I say who you are, I don't think anyone will stay for dinner.
Uh -- sorry -- to have stepped away for so long -- uh -- this is a friend of mine I asked to drop by --
Oh, I'm sorry.  This is my daughter, Allison, and her husband, Quince, Drew, my number one, works with me...
Oh, excuse me.  This is -- uh --
Sorry...um - you - you know it's gone right out of my head --
I'm sorry.  This is - uh - uh...
Joe knows what you're saying, just being polite --
Uh -- he's from out of town --
Uh - will that hold you, Joe?
We've got some things to discuss.
You and I've got to talk.  Big day tomorrow, everybody.  Joe, let's go.
Shook me up.  I mean that you knew her and everything --
So there's nothing between you and Susan?
I wish you had said something to me about staying here --
No, I'm okay with this - uh - I think.  So --
Box springs, they're assembled in Jakarta.  Had to stay in a station manager's house there unexpectedly - best night's sleep I ever had.
Thank you.  Would you like the man's name?
If there is anything else, don't hesitate --
...I just saw my doctor, he told me everything was fine.
Well, thank you for letting me know.
Mr. Black's luggage was misplaced by the airlines.  Would you mind get-
How are you?  How're you feeling?
Um -- well, I didn't sleep too well.
Tell you what, you promised that it's going to be only me and --
And I won't tell anyone who you are.
You give your word, I give mine --
You know, I got to thinking last night -- with you here, and seem-
How about giving a guy a break?
-- I don't deserve this.  I'm still young, this is not my time --
What's it like where I'm going?
You know, everyday I've walked into this building, Jaime gives me a horse.
I wonder if any of them won.
-- And call my family, I'd like them to come over for dinner tonight.
Perhaps you would like to wait in my office --?
What I'm trying to say is this is a Board meeting and you are not a mem-
-- This is Joe Black, a personal associate of mine - uh - he'll be joining us today.  I know it's --
Would you like to sit down, Joe?
Umm -- I did enjoy -- or rather I was interested in meeting John yes-
Sorry.  I know it looks like I'm reversing my field.
Well said, Eddie.  Mr. Black, shall we?
-- What's the deal here?  Are you going to be breathing down my neck right 'til the very end?
...I'd like to be alone for a while.
Yes, I am.  There's a research lib-
Joe, could I ask you to take a walk?
Now I'd like to be alone.
Here -- this will hold you for a while.
You know about money, don't you?
Jennifer, give Mr. Black a map of the city.
Cold lamb sandwich with cilantro.  A little Coleman's mustard.
Glad you like it.  My wife turned me onto cold lamb sandwiches.  Joan --
Cold lamb sandwiches -- not as chewy as roast beef, not as boring as chicken.  She knew stuff like that.
I thought you'd heard a trillion times --
She had on this little blue suit --
You could have put her under glass and I would have just stood and looked at her.  But when she spoke -- I loved the sound of her voice and her laugh --
-- I couldn't get enough of her --
Joe and I have no secrets from each other.
Joe, cut it out.  And you too, Drew.
Well now it's undone, okay?  Forget Bontecou!  Scrub him!  I'm tired of his fancy name and his fancy offer.
I don't want anybody buying up my life's work and turning it into something it wasn't meant to be.  A man wants to leave something behind.
And I don't need your goddamn permis-
I like it.  I like it.  I'm sorry I don't seem more appreciative.
I was a little abrupt with you this afternoon, Drew.  Forgive me.  I want you to know I value your advice.
Please.  Don't worry about him.  And above all, don't antagonize him.
-- I - uh - want to thank you all for coming - uh - my family --
-- Allison and Quince, Susan -- and the other members --
-- I'm so happy when we can get together -- I mean I know you all have busy lives --
Anyway -- I remember when you were little girls --
And now you're all grown up -- and I'm - uh - um --
I had some words all prepared but now I've forgotten them - uh - um -
Uh, it's gone...um -- it was on the tip of my tongue.
Anyway, I'd like to go on but...
There is so much I would like to say -- but I can't --
So I better sit down.  Carry on, everybody.
One other thing -- why don't we all have dinner again tomorrow night?
Why did you go to the hospital?
What way would you put it?
How about you telling me?  When I ask a simple question, I expect a straight answer.  That's what I'm used to.  Anybody who doesn't give it to me, I fire.
Do you mind if I raise a little caution flag?
What is the nature of your interest in Joe?
I won't say you may be getting onto shaken ground --
I don't think this is the lightning you are looking for.  Drew's a good man.  I know I didn't seem to be completely in his corner before, but I've come to appreciate --
I'm sorry, honey.  I'm no good at this.  Why don't you choose whatever cake you like?
What is there to say?  They know what John Bontecou is -- and if they didn't, they know now.
I'm feeling real uncomfortable right now because the guy who reports to me is threatening me.
I think it's time you went home, Drew.
Hello.  Would you like to join me, Quince and Allison for a nightcap?
I don't think so.  Do you?
The answer is no, quick enough for you?
I'm not interested in the details.
Yes, you are to understand that, and now may I ask you a question?
Are you running this Board or am I?

Doesn't need to.  Today, tomorrow, a week from now -- 'a week from now', who can think about a week from now -- the answer is going to be the same -- a loud, unmistakable, all-inclusive, airtight -- 'No'.
That's it?  I've got a busy day and this meeting has already set me behind.  Shall we adjourn?
I've already introduced Mr. Black to you all.
Thank you for allowing me to save face, Drew.
Yes, the big 'celebration' of my mandatory retirement birthday.
What 'okay' is, it's 'okay' it's over.  We've got bigger fish to fry, don't we, Joe?
Never mind.  I'm tired.  I'm going to take a nap.
Are you hungry?  Coyle will have Luisa fix you something to eat.
No, I'll come down  Joe waits guardedly at the bottom of the stairs as Parrish descends.
Well, you're at the wrong place at the wrong time with the wrong woman.
Well, you goddam well should.  You walk into my life, give me the worst news a guy can get, have me dancing on the heads of pins with my busi-
Yes, and stop repeating everything I sai, and turning it into a question.
You're violating the laws of the universe.
Any universe that exists or ever existed.  You may be the pro, Joe.
And I don't give a shit.
Cut the 'Bill' crap out -- you sonofabitch.
Why are you looking for Joe?
You don't know anything about Joe --
Susan, I don't think Joe is going to be with us long.
I don't know, I can't say --
In this case, I can't.  I - uh -- I just can't help you.  I only would tell you -- that with Joe, you are on very, very dangerous ground.
I don't care if you love him!  I'm telling you he's no good for you!
What are you saying, that it's time to go?
Fine, fine.  Big doing up here.  Why are you still down here?
Eddie, hold out all the hope you want but, I promise you, it's hope-
If you're trying to show me lay-
Okay, Eddie -- anyway, thanks for the memory.
It's starting to grow on me.  But what do the 'B' and 'P' mean?
You are amazing.  Why, oh why, Allison, are you doing all this?
Yeah?  And what about my enemies?
I haven't been the father to you that --
You know, darling, this is going to be a wonderful party.
No, I'm out of business, right, Quince?  However I do have some unfinished business -- with Drew.
All in all, what Bill wants to do is build the golden bridge to Drew with no hard feelings.
Quince, I've got confidence in you.
What the hell do you care?
You 'want to know', I'll tell you.
I thought we had a deal.
Susan is my daughter, she has a wonderful life ahead of her and you're going to deprive her of it and you're telling me you're sorry?  Well, I'm sorry, apology not accepted.
How perfect for you -- to take whatever you want because it pleases you.  It's not love --
Some aimless infatuation in which, for the moment, you feel like in-
Trust, responsibility, taking the weight, for your choices and feel-
Multiply it by infinity and take it to the death of forever and you will still have barely a glimpse of what I am talking about.
With you?!  Who is 'you'?  Did you tell her who you are?
Does she know where she's going?
Susan went, in whatever way she did, for that poor sonofabitch whose body you took, and everything else since has been aftermath.  You say you love her but you don't know what love is.

I certainly hope so -- I loved Susan from the moment she was born, and I love her now, and every minute in between, and what I dream of is a man who will discover her and she will discover a man who will love her, who is worthy of her, who is of this world, of this time and has the grace and compassion and fortitude to walk beside her as she makes her way through this beautiful thing called life.

Why did you come in here and tell me, Joe?  You are the Biggest Shot of all, you don't have to ask my permission, but that's what you're doing.  You know why?  Because you've somewhere, somehow, developed into a good guy, and you know this is all wrong... I don't know what you're going to do -- how can this be love?
Okay? -- I've given it my best shot.
...May? -- I know you're busy,  but I want you to put in a call to Eddie Sloane for me --
I appreciate this, Eddie, members of the Board, this will just take a minute of your time.  As the custo-
You're a worthless sack of shit, you fucked me over, played footsie with John Bontecou, sold my company out to line your own pockets.
The Board didn't know you're a mole who burrowed inside so you could bury us all.
It's not necessary, Joe.  Drew's going to step aside --
I told you to shut up.
Yes, he is.  He's an -- IRS man.
The Treasury Department asked my cooperation in his undercover investigation of John Bontecou.
No lawyers, Drew.  We're going to offer you a deal.
Confess to the Board every details of your participation and then submit your resignation.
You get not to go to jail.
Proof?  We've got plenty of proof.
Well, thank you, that's great, but it's more than I bargained for.  I just wanted to set the record straight.
I thought I was going to sneak away tonight...
...What a glorious night, every face I see is a memory.  It may not be a perfectly perfect memory --
I want you to know how much I love you.  That you've given a meaning to my life that I had no right to expect, and that no one can ever take from me.
No -- I love you so much and I want you to promise me something.  I don't want you to ever worry about me.  If anything should happen, I'm going to be fine and everything's going to be all right.
And I want you to feel that way, too.
It's a good feeling, isn't it?
Would you like to dance with me, Susan?
If you don't mind dancing with an old fogey like me.
You go ahead, honey, I'm going to catch my breath.
I guess you have your reasons.
Now that we have a moment, would you mind if I expressed my gratitude for what you did for Susan?
I never heard her speak of any man as she spoke of you -- It was always what I wanted for her -- but what happens to her now?
Don't blow smoke up my ass, you'll ruin my autopsy.
It's hard to let go, isn't it?
That's life.  What can I tell you?
I'm getting a little dizzy, I can feel my heart pumping --
It's going to be beautiful.  And Miss Allison says the President may come.
Telephone call, sir.  Mr. Sloane from New York.
Drew called from the AStar, they're still two minutes away.
He wanted to ride back down with you. Now sit and relax, get some-
Will you relax?  I know it is a big deal day --
I thought you were in a meeting--?
No, it's none of your business.
You mean like you loved Mom?
And I'm your daughter and no man will ever be good enough for me.
What were you going to say?
'Be deliriously happy'.  I'm going to do my upmost --
I'm sorry.  But give it to me again.
I won't.  And when I tell Drew about it, he won't either.
Not at all.  It was fascinating.
I was just being agreeable, now I've got to explain why?
I have an office in the hospital.
'Pro bono'.  That means doing good -- Going to be doing good all your life?
You'd give up what you want for the woman you marry?
You'll have a hard time finding a woman like that these days --
No, it was so right it scares me.
Sure, I'll give you the name of a doctor.
...And I don't want to examine you.
Because I like you so much.  Now I've got to go.
Hi, everybody.  Sorry to be late -
...I'm here, aren't I?  Wouldn't miss a loose end meeting.  What's on the table for discussion?  Party favors, flowers -- hi Dad, hi Drew --
-- This morning.  The Corinth Coffee Shop.  He was looking for a doctor.
So, what are you doing here?
Cat got your tongue?  You weren't so silent this morning.
Funny, I don't get that feeling.
-- Can't seem to escape you today.
Hand me one of those, will you?
You must have something really big going on with my father --
You appear at his side out-of-the-
Not the one I met this morning, hit-

What are your intentions?  To make little dreams in coffee shops, turn a woman's head, and I don't mind admitting it was turned, I liked it, but ten hours later I feel like a fool.  I don't get it.  You, my father, here in this house, the cof-
You act like you never had peanut butter before --
-- What kind of childhood did you have?
Drew is none of your damn business.
No, Joe, I'm swimming here.  Then I'm going home.
I'm sorry to say I know what you're saying.
I think you want to go to the west wing.  Through there.
Then why are you here, Joe?
I don't have any time to see you now.  I'm doing grand rounds and then I'm examining back-to-back patients until dinner and then --
That's impossible.  I'm a doctor, I'm --
Have you filled out the insurance forms?
Go with her.  I'll be right there.
Have you spent a lot of time in the islands?
Don't apologize.  There's nothing to be sorry for -- every hospital should have someone like you.
I have to go, I'm sorry to say --
Nothing's going on.  Maybe he doesn't want to be alone.  He's go-
I thought you said 'Be sorry for nothing'.
It wasn't an intrusion.  And if it was, it turned out to be welcome.
Haven't you had enough of us, Dad?
Why do you love peanut butter so much?
I adore things like that....food I can't do without.  Don't you?
We're doing what we can for her.
You don't mean that.  You wouldn't disappoint Daddy --
Sorry, but I like the way he looks and talks to me.  And vice versa.
How long have you been standing there?
Tell me about yourself, Joe.  Who you are.  What you're doing with my father.
So you're not going to tell me?
Because guys who never say anything about themselves are always married.
Then tell me, Joe, how come a man as attractive, intelligent, well-
I'm sorry, I don't want to pry and you don't want to tell me.  So let's leave it a mystery.  That's the way you want it, isn't it?
Yeah, it's good to get together.
Well, remember how you told me about "lightning striking"?  The nature of it's in there somewhere.
Now we love Drew and Joe in verbo-
When you say 'nothing' that way, it's not nothing.
Never talk to my father like that again.
Why don't you get off his case?
That's it.  It's over.  Get out.
Brave you had a chance to look at Dad's rare books?  Jefferson's Parliamentary Manual, a first edition Bleak House --
When I was little, my mother used to say, "Darling, you could set your heart by this clock".
I don't know who you are.
And is your heart beating strangely?
I just thought I'd drop by, scrounge a little lunch, I was in the neigh-
Just throw it on the chair.
When I called, they said that you and Daddy had just left the office.
He must be tired -- this Bontecou thing --
Maybe it's the draft through the door.
It's so wonderful to make love to you.  It's like making love to some-
Did you like making love to me?
More than you love peanut butter?
Because I was sitting in a staff meeting, incredibly bored, my mind kept wandering and the only place it landed was -- Joe.
Love.  Passion.  Obsession, all those things you told me to wait for.  Well, they've arrived.
Why?  A man appears at your side, almost never leaves it, you clearly trust him, depend on him, I sense you value him deeply, why aren't those things good enough for me?
What are you afraid of, Dad?  That I'll fall head over heels for Joe --
C'mon!  The guy's working with you.
Of course not, Daddy.  I'm sorry.
I like you in a black tie.
It beats a surgical, doesn't it?
Daddy told me you might be leaving?
And you can't tell me who you are.
I'm in love with a man, I don't know who he is, where he's going or when.
We know all that we need to know --
Lightning struck.  We caught it in a bottle.  Don't let it out.  I want to be with you, Joe --
Yes, that's why I said it.
There's something so indescribably sexy about you in a crowd.  I could make love to you right here.
If you're going to tell my future, you're on the wrong side.
Remember that morning in the coffee shop?  You said 'What's wrong with taking care of a woman, she takes care of you --"
And I said you'd have a hard time finding a woman like that.
-- That was the place... and you were the guy.
And you said you didn't want me to be your doctor because you didn't want me to examine you --?
Well, I got to examine you after all --
You want me to wait for you, you'll be back --
Why do I want this night to last forever?
You said before you couldn't tell me who or where, only the 'when' -- Is when now?
What's going on, Joe?  I feel like we're lifting off --
But you're not.  You're somewhere else.
Tell me you love me -- tell me you love me now --
You were right about Joe, he is going somewhere --
Oh, Dad, you're not old.  You'll never be old.
The fireworks are about to start.
I said I liked you so much.
...We know so little about each other.
I wish you could've known my father...
What do you do that for?
I am, this is it.  B Day.
Bontecou Day.  Going to close with Big John -- Look at you, Bill, all cool as a cat and over at Bontecou's, I'll bet he's shitting in his pants.
Okay.  All aboard - New York, New York!
Hey, this is it, the hour approach-
I know.  Gum up the works.
He said he would be there with bells on.
No jocks?  A twenty-game winner or a Masters champion?  Someone I could talk to.
I don't think they're ordinary.  I love keychains.
You bet.  I'm kind of my Rotisserie League.
Yeah, they hit the calf over the head with a mallet and then Luisa hits it again in the kitchen.
You know what I'm saying, Joe?
Well, I guess he's found one.
Don't bother asking, we already tried.
...I read you all the way on the Bontecou thing, and I know where you're coming from.  And I'm with you a hundred and one percent.
But I've got to tell you, if mergers are in the wild, I've got some great prospects I've developed.  I want to talk to you about them next week.
Joe, you don't know how glad I am you're aboard.  Anybody who can take some of the weight off the old man, I'm in his corner.
No problem.  I'll leave you two alone.  I can tell you guys have something on the fire --
...I know you're down, but you know when you're down, Drew, there's no place to go but up.
Never mind Bontecou.  I've got some other merger possibilities up my sleeve, and I'm putting them to see old man.
We'll do it together.  I'll clue you in.  Timing's got to be right.  The old man says it's up to Joe.

Mandatory retirement upon our Chairman's sixty-fifth birthday.

You're the poison, Drew.  You've operated behind-the-scenes to suborn the trust of a man who has stamped you with his imprimatur of class and elegance and stature.  I've seen all kinds and degrees of deception in my time, but Bill Parrish has been on the receiving end of machinations so Machiavellian that it has rarely been my experience to encounter.  And yet he has combatted them stoically, and selflessly, without revealing my identity.  Had he violated the vow of secrecy he took, his task would have been far easier, he could have turned defeat into victory, but he is too honorable a man to have done that.  And now I must release him from that vow.  Because of me, he has lost his work, his company, his reputation -- and now he's going to tell you who I am.
